Posts.Content: Aug 8, 2011 08:55PM atlanta01 wrote: Hi Beanpole - I don't think you're complaining!  Yes I am still waiting - Monday, August 15th.  The waiting has made for a less than delightful summer! There are definitely pros and cons to socialized medicine - it's not free (we have really high taxes) and there are long wait times for lots of procedures and tests and doctors don't stay in Canada - they do better financially and academically in the USA.   Carolyn
Posts.Title: Would you wait 2-3 weeks for a biopsy? Beanpole DocBabs

Posts.Content: Aug 8, 2011 06:52PM atlanta01 wrote: I had my regular mammogram on June 7th and my diagnostic mammogram on June 16th.  I was called on June 20th by my family doctor saying she was faxing a request for a stereotactic biopsy to the Breast Health Centre but I could call to schedule the appointment (I have a doctor that does the least she has to).  I called and was scheduled for August 15th.  They only do 3 a day and it's the only facility in the city that I live in (I'm in Canada).  I will have waited 9 weeks before the biopsy is done.  This is definitely not what I want and the waiting is unbearable.  I asked the Breast Health Centre scheduler if people were scheduled on a priority basis and was told that the scheduling is basically "first come, first served".  I really hope that if further treatment is required (and it probably will be in my case), that the wait is not as long.  I have always been an empowered patient and I won't hesitate to use that empowerment to make sure that the wait is not as long as this one has been.   Sorry to sound so upset but as it gets closer to the date, I realize how long I've had to wait and how helpless we are when our health is an issue in a place with a definite lack of testing and diagnostic facilities.
Posts.Title: Would you wait 2-3 weeks for a biopsy? Beanpole DocBabs

Posts.Content: Aug 11, 2011 10:19AM atlanta01 wrote: Thanks Gottobeme - I appreciate what you have said.  I think right now I am just so frustrated with the wait time and the medical system here that I tend to overreact to just about anything right now! I was successful in getting a copy of the diagnostic mammogram report today and although the report shows pleomorphic linear calcifications in 2 separate areas, I at least know what was found and what the outcome could potentially be.  I have done a lot of research so I'm not going into the procedure on Monday thinking all is well - I know there is the potential for this to be DCIS and I am prepared for that. Thanks to everyone here that supports all of us, especially the new members - it helps to be able to connect with someone that knows exactly what we are going through. Carolyn
Posts.Title: Would you wait 2-3 weeks for a biopsy? Beanpole DocBabs

Posts.Content: Aug 10, 2011 11:15AM atlanta01 wrote: Hi Gottobeme I have definitely taken the time to educate myself on the procedures, possible diagnosis and options that are available and it has been the best thing for me.  However, I still feel that 9 weeks is too long to have to wait for a biopsy and that in our province, the government needs to take a look at the wait times.  We've had hallway medicine for over 10 years with little or no resolution and no solutions.  I don't fault the health care providers, I fault the system. I have been patient as there is nothing I can do to speed up the process but that doesn't mean that the anxiety has not been heightened and had a huge impact on my day to day living.  This is who I am and I can't change that.

Posts.Content: Sep 24, 2011 10:09AM atlanta01 wrote: Hi Ginarn The hardness you are feeling is most likely scar tissue.  I was told before my biopsy that I would have an area around the needle insertion point that would be hard and it would eventually go away. Hope this helps Carolyn
Posts.Title: Hard area at biopsy site ginarn ginarn

Posts.Content: atlanta01 wrote: I found this site three weeks ago when I was looking for information about microcalcifications.  I had my regular two year screening mammogram on June 7, 2011.  I have been going for mammograms since I was 40 (I'm now 56).  I had a breast reduction in 2008 and thought that this would make mammograms so much more reliable.  I never gave a second thought to my mammograms until I received a call on June 20th from my FP saying I needed to go for a diagnostic mammogram.  She said there were some calcifications and I needed another mammogram.  I asked her what these were and she said, "Don't worry, this happens a lot and it's probably nothing to worry about".  I went for the diagnostic mammogram and 2 days later my FP called to say I was going to be scheduled for a stereotactic core biopsy.  Up to that phone call I hadn't thought that anything might be wrong and I believed that the diagnostic mammogram wouldn't show anything.   I have had some issues with my FP (my former FP retired last year and this doctor is new to the practice, having just finished her medical training and residency last June).  I didn't think to call her back and ask exactly what was found on the diagnostic mammogram and I began reading a lot of the information on this site.  I made an appointment and met with my doctor on Friday morning.  I told her that I wanted to know exactly what was showing on the mammograms and what the radiologist indicated in his/her report.  She said there were 2 linear calcifications on the outer lower aspect of my left breast and the medial lower aspect.   My biopsy is not scheduled until August 15th (although I live in Canada where there is socialized medical care, it comes with some drawbacks - shortages of doctors and clinics that perform these procedures.  In my city, there is only one clinic that performs these procedures and they only do 3 a day so there is a 6 week waiting period......). I have a wonderful husband and he has been very supportive but like many spouses/partners, he reassures me by saying "everything will be okay".  I have tried to be strong and say that I know this but last night I broke down and had my first long cry.   I know that this is a very supportive discussion board and I think I need this support now.   Thank you for letting me bare my soul! Carolyn  Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: This is me-not diagnosed but worried atlanta01 MamaMia41

Posts.Content: Jul 21, 2011 02:21PM atlanta01 wrote: Hi VSM Thank you for the encouraging words this morning!  I have seen the radiologyassistant site and got some valuable information from it that allowed me to ask the right questions when I went to the doctor.  I really have been trying to focus on the positives and since my meltdown a few nights ago, things have been a lot more stable!   MamaMia41 - I started this whole journey (I know it's not much of a journey right now but it's a side trip for me) by researching the stereotactic core biopsy.  I'm like you, the more you know, the less the worry.  I like knowing what is going to happen and I also have found some information that will allow me to ask specific questions before and after the procedure.   I have found that I really need to be proactive because my doctor really tends to brush things off and I don't like that approach.  As I have some other health issues right now, I can't change physicians at this time - as soon as I can, I will find another doctor.   Again ladies - thank you for the support and encouragement - I hope that I can do the same for you!

Posts.Content: Aug 1, 2011 10:29AM atlanta01 wrote: Hi WorriedSick33 You have come to the right place.  There are many of us in the same place as you and I can say that I have learned more since I joined this site and received so much support from those that are also waiting for tests and results and from the various topics on this site. You are not alone in feeling sick and crying - we've all been there and I started on this site after I had a crying meltdown one evening.  I have been waiting for almost 9 weeks for my scheduled biopsy on August 15th.  I know that the waiting is difficult and Googling lots of sites can add to the anxiety.  I have quit Googling any other sites and instead have read all I can on this site. Posts.Content: Aug 24, 2011 02:49PM - edited Aug 24, 2011 04:26PM by atlanta01 Hi Cindy I am also waiting for biopsy results.  I had my biopsy done on August 15th and was told the results would be available within 2 weeks.  Prior to the procedure, I had some good and some bad days. Since the procedure I have had mornings where I have meltdowns for a few minutes and then can't stop thinking about the possible outcome.  I have tried to stay positive as well but each day seems to become more difficult.  I know that for me, once I have the results, I will be able to make the appropriate decisions.  Hang in there - I will be thinking of you and hope you get good results tomorrow. Carolyn

Posts.Title: scared and worried like never before... scaredmommyof6 SarahsMom

Posts.Content: atlanta01 wrote: My initial mammogram was June 7, 2011 with a diagnostic mammogram for calcifications in one breast on June 16, 2011.  I had a 9 week wait for a stereotactic biopsy which was done on August 15, 2011.  I was told that the results would be back within 2 weeks and my PCP would provide me with the results. I went to my PCP's office yesterday to see if they had the results and the receptionist looked through the computer file and said there was nothing yet and then she said the two words no one waiting for results ever wants to hear - "Don't worry".  I didn't know whether to scream at her or to do what I seem to do best these days and start crying.  Instead, I looked her straight in the eyes and said, very matter of factly, "I AM WORRIED" and I left the office. As I was driving out of the parking lot, she came running out and told me that there is no record of a biopsy being done in the office.  I told her I didn't have a biopsy in the office, I had a biopsy at the Breast Health Centre.  She said, "OH" and I said, "Now you should know why I am worried".  She got some details from me and said she'd check with the BHC either that afternoon or today and would get back to me.  She told me she had worked at the BHC and understood what I was going through (I doubt it!) and then, she called me "Dear" and said "Have a good day".   I appreciate that many people don't know what to say when someone has a health issue, but to have someone in a medical office that doesn't know what the situation is brush a patient's concern off is reprehensible.   I will be calling the Breast Health Centre myself today to see if they have received the results.  I know they can't provide the results to me but if I know they have been released to my PCP, I will go back to the office and request them from her.   I have never been one to accept the status quo but this situation over the past 2 months has made me realize that we need to be empowered women where our health is concerned.   Carolyn  Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Aug 26, 2011 11:50AM atlanta01 wrote: I finally got my results and they are benign.  I have calcifications and necrosis and will be monitored annually now to ensure nothing changes.   I'm so thankful for all the support I have received here and wish each and every one of you all the best that you so deserve. Carolyn
Posts.Title: Still Waiting.... atlanta01 Zombean80

Posts.Content: Aug 27, 2011 05:08PM atlanta01 wrote: Cycle-path - WIsh I could change but I live in a city where there is only one breast health centre.  I live in Canada and although we all have access to health care, we also have long wait times and lack of adequate resources.  The government in our Province has even started posting wait times for various procedures and the average wait time for breast biopsies is 7 weeks - I had to wait 9 weeks! Screening mammograms are done in one centre in the city I live in and there are 4 other centres located throughout the Province.  There is a mobile unit that travels to remote communities. Diagnostic mammograms are done in 2 locations in the city and all other breast procedures at the Breast Health Centre.  The staff there are frustrated by the lack of funding and staff to accomodate all the requests for procedures. So you see, although we have facilities, we're limited and don't have the option to go elsewhere. If I could have gone somewhere else, believe me, I would have gone. Carolyn
Posts.Title: Still Waiting.... atlanta01 Zombean80
